title: Arthur Campbell Ainger
text:
Arthur Campbell Ainger (4 July 1841, in <a href="Greenwich%2C%20Kent">Greenwich, Kent</a> – 26 October 1919, in Mustians, <a href="Eton%2C%20Berkshire">Eton, Berkshire</a>) was an assistant master at <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a> and a writer of Christian lyrics for hymns, most notably "<a href="God%20Is%20Working%20His%20Purpose%20Out">God Is Working His Purpose Out</a>" (1894).
Arthur Ainger, whose father was Rev. <a href="Thomas%20Ainger">Thomas Ainger</a>, was educated at Eton College and in 1860 matriculated at <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity College, Cambridge</a>; there he became a Scholar in 1863 and received B.A. (16th in <a href="Classical%20Tripos">Classics Tripos</a>) in 1864 and M.A. in 1867. He was an assistant master at Eton College from 1864 to 1901. At Trinity College, Cambridge, he gave two Clark Lectures: "Chaucer" (1900) and "Shakespeare as a humorist" (1901). He was appointed Member of the <a href="Royal%20Victorian%20Order">Royal Victorian Order</a> (MVO) in 1908.
Ainger wrote several books and the texts for more than ten hymns.
